clinical_study.brief_title: Screening for Convergence Insufficiency in School-age Children
clinical_study.official_title: Screening Eye Coordination Study Screening for Convergence Insufficiency in School-age Children

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study was to assess the ability of common tests of eye alignment, convergence, and accommodation to identify children with convergence insufficiency in a school screening setting.

detailed_description.textblock: The purpose of the Screening for Convergence Insufficiency in School-age Children study was to assess the ability of common tests of eye alignment, convergence, and accommodation to identify children with convergence insufficiency in a school screening setting (where it may not be feasible to do more than one test).

study_pop.textblock: Of the 282 subjects included in the analysis, approximately 60% were female, 81.5% identified themselves as white, 11% as African American, 2.5% as other, and 5% did not report race. Two percent classified themselves as Hispanic or Latino, 76% reported not being Hispanic or Latino, and 22% did not report their ethnicity.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age 9 to 17 years
- Enrolled in participating school
- Parental permission, assent
- Ability to complete testing
Exclusion criteria: referral on vision screening for reduced distance visual acuity or significant uncorrected refractive error

facility.name: The Ohio State University College of Optometry
